final_answer:
The humor and satire in the image come from the visual and textual contrast between the two pages of the book. On the left, a person is dressed formally, and on the right, the same person is undressed, revealing only underwear. Both individuals have visible tattoos. The text "YES," and "BUT" adds to the irony, suggesting that appearances can be deceiving or that judgments based on clothing might not tell the full story.

The humor lies in the unexpected juxtaposition of the formally dressed and undressed person, challenging stereotypes about professionalism, identity, and how tattoos are perceived in different contexts. It pokes fun at superficial assumptions made about people based on their appearance.
